The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that have been hypothesized to have evolved from free-living cnidarians. However, the origin of this group has remained elusive. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two distantly related myxozoans, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister group to P. hydriforme. In addition, we find that myxozoans have one of the smallest reported animal genomes and that gene content and expression are reduced relative to other parasitic and nonparasitic cnidarians. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This is likely a consequence of the parasitic lifestyle, which requires a small genome and a reduction in gene content to minimize the metabolic burden on the host. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian. (Read more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops. We quantify how the variability of maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in most of the world’s maize-producing countries. This increase in variability will increase the probability that a country will have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. Our results highlight the importance of breeding for heat tolerance, which will be critical to maintain maize productivity in the future. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

Large mammalian herbivores (LMH) are a dominant component of many ecosystems, and their grazing has been linked to ecosystem functioning and biodiversity. However, the extent to which LMH partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of plant remains in dung. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven LMH species in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that LMH are highly specialized in their consumption of food plants, and that diet composition differs between species even when they are similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results have implications for understanding the role of LMH in ecosystems and for the management of LMH in conservation and agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study also highlights the need for a global monitoring program to assess the magnitude of the problem and to assess the effectiveness of mitigation efforts. This program should be based on a global network of regional surveys. Such a program is currently being developed by the authors. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is one of the most intriguing questions in presolar grain research. They are found in meteorites and in the solar system. However, the origin of the SiC grains is still a mystery. We determined the ages of 40 large SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that the majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. A minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This result has important implications for the origin of SiC grains. We also found that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. This result is important for the understanding of the formation of the solar system. (Show more)

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could expand by 1 million more motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources. The expansion of the motorized fleet has been driven by the powered-artisanal sector, which has grown substantially in recent decades. We provide a global reconstruction of the powered-artisanal fleet and its evolution since 1950. The ability to produce offspring is a fundamental characteristic of all living organisms. In this study, we examine the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals. We find that the greatest factor limiting reproductive output is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. We also find that all forms of external provisioning, including domestication, correlate with increased reproductive output. Finally, we find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This finding has implications for understanding the evolution of mammalian reproductive strategies and the origins of domestication. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and its monomeric and oligomeric forms. Finally, VX-765 showed neuroprotective effects by preserving tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of MSA mice. In conclusion, our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to multiple stimuli. The endothelium is connected in a network of cells that is responsible for coordinating the activities of the cells. The network is composed of clusters of cells that are connected to each other by short paths. The network is highly efficient in the transmission of information and is able to rapidly respond to changes in the environment. These properties are important for the endothelium to control the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In response, we have developed a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through an API, allowing researchers to easily access and combine the data. The data are relevant to a wide range of research and policy questions, and we hope that the data will be useful to the research community and to policy makers.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including the control of heart rate, blood pressure, and blood glucose levels. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a molecular explanation for the structural changes that occur in the selectivity filter during inactivation. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the understanding of the physiological function of potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the environment. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is becoming increasingly recognized, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could be used as a source of therapeutics. We identify 146 genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for natural products in four representative anaerobic fungi. We also identify a number of natural products that are likely to be produced by these fungi. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are capable of synthesizing natural products and provide a foundation for future studies to investigate the potential of these fungi to be used as a source of natural products. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. In this study, we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes an individual to become subordinate in a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness of high-anxious individuals is associated with a lack of the ability to become dominant in a dyadic contest. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior. (PsycInfo Database Record

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the material properties and the structure of the devices. Here, we develop a strategy to synthesize and assemble materials with distinct properties into structures that exhibit programmable behaviors. The synthesized structures are then used to design devices with complex and programmable behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture devices with specific behaviors for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design and manufacture mechanical devices with programmable behaviors.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is a function of the developmental stage of the cells. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in adult bone marrow and fetal liver but is silenced in erythroid cells. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can reprogram the hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be a potential target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of targeted therapies, many patients do not respond to treatment or relapse. Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the development of resistance to therapy is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We also found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis. These findings suggest that combination of ferroptosis induction with targeted therapy may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. The underlying mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are complex and not fully understood. Here, we show that the major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate STIM1, which in turn activates ORAI1 channels. LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM1-mediated ORAI1 activation. Our findings indicate that LCCBs may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of heart failure. Our data also indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of LCCBs in the development of heart failure. (PsycInfo Database Record

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal lands. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations in early-seral ecosystems, but that the policy failed to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of older forests, and the policy’s effects on older forests are still unclear. The NWFP is a unique case study for evaluating the influence of policy. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management. We recommend that the NWFP be evaluated in the context of the science that has emerged since its implementation. © 2017, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Therefore, the development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. We used a computational model to predict the membrane permeability and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics toward the ribosome. We then synthesized the top candidates and tested them in vitro. Finally, we tested the in vivo activity of the best candidates against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher membrane permeability, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. This approach can be used to design new antibiotics in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common. However, the biological effects of this technology on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use in the hours before bedtime. This study also highlights the need for more research on the biological effects of electronic devices on sleep and health. (PsycINFO Database Record

The YDB is a chronostratigraphic marker used to define the start of the last glaciation. However, the origin of the osmium in the YDB is unknown. CTLA-4 is a well-known regulator of immune responses, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that the absence of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. This was not fatal, but led to the development of autoantibodies against multiple organs. In addition, we show that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and their feeding habits. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These results have important implications for understanding the origin and evolution of animal diversity. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also have broader implications for the development of other protein-based therapeutics.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that, contrary to expectations, larger populations do not enhance CCE. Instead, we found that the greater variation participants had access to in the larger populations may have overwhelmed their working memory and weakened their ability to selectively copy the best-adapted plane(s). Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. This study highlights the importance of trial-and-error learning to the innovation and adaptation of artifacts. Our results have implications for the evolution of intelligence, the origins of culture, and the development of technology. They also have implications for the design of education and training programs. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for AD. APOE is expressed in many cell types in the brain, but its role in AD is not understood. We found that APOE is expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. APOE2 also enhances the rate of clearance of senescent synapses from the brain. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies may help to understand the pathogenesis of AD. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 2,300 km. It is the densest part of the Earth. The inner core is thought to have formed by the rapid solidification of the core material. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the bcc phase of iron is more stable than the hcp phase under the inner core conditions. Thus, the bcc phase is likely to be the first phase to nucleate in the core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. They also have implications for the origin of other dense solids. (Read more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well-known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. Our findings also highlight the importance of studying the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain.

Language is a uniquely human skill. It is also a uniquely complex skill. How the human brain processes language is a central question in cognitive neuroscience. Here, we use the most powerful artificial intelligence (AI) models to make novel predictions about the human brain in language comprehension. Our results show that AI models trained on language data can explain nearly 100% of the neural and behavioral variance in language processing. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that AI models may be a powerful tool for understanding the brain. This approach could be extended to other complex cognitive and social skills.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it has been shown that many problems are ill-conditioned, meaning that the solutions are unstable. We show that this instability is not a consequence of the DL method, but rather a fundamental property of the problem. We also introduce a new algorithm that is stable for a large class of problems. This work is a step toward understanding the stability of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a textbook example of the failure of social distancing. The failure is often attributed to a lack of understanding of exponential growth. This paper shows that this attribution is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. The experiment’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of the study of human response to exponential growth. We discuss the flaws and the implications for the study of human response to exponential growth.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-affecting disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the skin disease lepromatous leprosy. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably similar, despite their ancient separation. This suggests that the two bacteria have retained many of the same genes, and that the genes that have been lost are not essential for survival. This is important for understanding the evolution of the disease and the development of new therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The emergence of thermodynamics from quantum dynamics is a central problem in quantum mechanics. In the simplest case of a pure state, the system remains at zero entropy during the evolution. However, the system is isolated, and its evolution is not constrained by the laws of thermodynamics. Therefore, the system must acquire entropy, which is the accumulated entanglement. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a consequence of integrability. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our result has implications for the study of entanglement dynamics in general isolated systems.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The development of a vaccine against COVID-19 is of utmost importance to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, COVI-VAC, that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet robustly grows at the permissive temperature. In addition, the vaccine is devoid of the furin cleavage site within the spike protein, which is known to be a safety concern. The vaccine generates high levels of spike-specific antibodies in hamsters and protects them from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. These results support the potential of the vaccine for use in mass vaccination programs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been responsible for some of the largest population declines in human history, including the Black Death (1347–1353), which led to the death of 30–60% of the European population. Today, plague is still a major public health concern, with the most common transmission pathways being rodent or flea-borne. However, little is known about the historical spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites fits the mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or flea-borne transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for the control of plague today. © 2022, The Author(s).

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience for more than a century. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the product of both size and number of neurons, has been largely neglected. This study provides a comprehensive reconstruction of the evolution of brain power across amniotes. We show that the evolution of brain power is characterized by four major shifts. The most dramatic increase in brain power happened with the origin of birds and mammals. This is a result of convergent evolution in these two endothermic lineages. The other three increases in brain power happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates. We discuss the implications of our findings for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results also have implications for the evolution of human intelligence.

Mitochondrial HSP90 (TRAP1) is a molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here, we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Actin filaments are the major structural elements of the cytoskeleton. They are dynamic, and their structure and function are regulated by a number of proteins. One of these proteins, cofilin, is responsible for severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which cofilin does so is not well understood. Here, we show that the mechanical properties of the actin filament network in which cofilin acts play a critical role in determining the severing rate constant. We propose a mechanochemical model that explains our results. This model may be relevant to the function of cofilin in cells. Our findings may also have implications for the design of materials. For example, we show that the mechanical properties of the network in which cofilin acts can be used to tune the severing rate constant. This may be useful in the design of materials that are robust to mechanical stress. (Read more)

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, the sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative effects of fructose and glucose on appetite and food-seeking behavior have not been well characterized. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes greater hunger and desire for food and a willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger stimulus for feeding behavior than glucose. Thus, the health benefits of fructose may be more modest than previously thought. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the human history of Madagascar. It also provides a reference for the genomic diversity of the Malagasy people, which is a unique population. This information will be useful for the conservation of the Malagasy people and their biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. This work shows that people do not need to be in close proximity to each other to be influenced by the emotions of others. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, as well as for our understanding of the mechanisms of emotional contagion. Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary targets of translation regulation. However, there is a growing appreciation that mRNAs can also be posttranscriptionally modified, and that these modifications can have profound effects on protein synthesis. Here, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in mRNA coding regions can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our results suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA coding regions and that this can have a small effect on translation. This is an important finding, as the vast majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions. Our work also highlights the importance of considering the context of mRNA modifications when studying the effects of these modifications on protein synthesis. (Read more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social engagement, and a healthier lifestyle. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of aquatic life has been a major driver of the evolution of mammals. We use a combination of comparative analysis and the fossil record to test the extent to which aquatic life has driven the evolution of body size in mammals. We find that the evolution of aquatic life has driven the evolution of body size in all four extant aquatic mammal clades. This is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of body size in mammals and the evolution of aquatic life.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a failure of the host antiviral response at cool temperatures. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more efficient antiviral response at 37 °C than at 33 °C. This difference in the magnitude of the antiviral response accounts for the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication. Our findings have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Read more)

Bacteria use a variety of sensors to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensitive system is required for attachment to surfaces, and results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment and virulence. This system is reminiscent of the mechanosensitive chemosensory system used by many bacteria to sense the environment. Our results demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor for surfaces. This system may be used by other bacteria to sense surfaces and promote attachment and virulence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. This risk is highest for newer-generation insecticides, which are more toxic than older generations. The risk is also higher in countries with less stringent environmental regulations. These results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread globally and is now endemic. The virus has been detected in a variety of animal species, including dogs, cats, and bats. However, the potential for SARS-CoV-2 to persist in wildlife and the implications for human health remain unclear. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species of conservation concern in North America. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. They also highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2 in wildlife. This will be critical to inform effective disease surveillance and control measures. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper studies the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species, which are known to be the most toxic, are responsible for the activation of immune cells within the brain. We also demonstrate that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is a significant risk factor for the development of AD. These findings provide insight into the early stages of AD and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still lacking. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in this region. Our results suggest that the early adoption of chickens in European husbandry was preceded by at least a century by the adoption of this species in the Southern Levant. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the early history of this species and its integration into the economy of the ancient world. (Read more)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not understood. We have developed a method to study the folding of a large protein in high structural detail. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that is known to have a distinct native-like folding intermediate. We find that the folding of the protein is a multistep process, with a distinct intermediate in each step. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This list is growing, and it is becoming clear that the folding of proteins is more complex than previously thought. (Read more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to RNA caps, which are required for their biological activity. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the caps from transcripts in response to stress assumes a leading role in deprotecting those same transcripts. This enzyme, which is normally inactive in the presence of stress, recognizes capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which this enzyme recognizes capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of action is the induction of immunosuppression. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is able to restore the immune system function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental property of the planet that is still poorly understood. Here, we provide a census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also show that the biomass of marine life is underestimated and that the biomass of consumers is higher than that of producers. Finally, we highlight the impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a step forward toward understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems with a simple structure exhibit complex behavior. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, with a vanishing bandgap, by applying tensile strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, with a fully metallic state, by applying compressive strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are also relevant for other materials, such as graphene, which can be metallized and demetallized by strain. The role of plant immune peptides in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the structure and antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula. The structure of the peptide was largely disordered and dynamic. However, it exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of the peptide was revealed by structural and functional studies. The peptide bound to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and induced reactive oxygen species in germlings of the fungal pathogen. The peptide also exhibited strong fungal cell wall binding and penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. The results provide insights into the structural basis of the antifungal activity of the NCR peptide. This work also paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive axis is a model system for understanding the molecular mechanisms of intersexual continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular mechanisms of intersexual continuity. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the pathophysiology of VWD. We also show that the effects of VWD mutations on VWF binding to platelets can be explained by the switch model. This work provides a mechanism for the effects of mutations in VWF and a method for treating VWD. This work also provides a model for the effects of mutations in other proteins that bind to receptors on the surface of cells. This work is relevant to the fields of hemostatic disorders, biophysics, and cell biology. (Read more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that interact with humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. Here, we present a database of human-associated viruses, which is the first of its kind. We find that the human virome is associated with many diseases, and that the human microbiome is enriched for viruses that are associated with a disease. This study will help to advance the field of human microbiome research.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in climate models. This is because of the complexity of ACI and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL can measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI. The results show that the HSRL can provide new insights into ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This instrument will be a significant contribution to the climate science.

The origin of life is one of the most important questions in science. One of the most fundamental aspects of the origin of life is the temperature of the early Earth. This study provides a new method for determining the temperature of the early Earth.

Ion channels are important for the normal function of the nervous system and heart. They are also involved in a variety of diseases, including heart failure, epilepsy, and stroke. Ion channels are regulated by two types of gates, activation and inactivation, that control the flow of ions across the membrane. Inactivation gates are commonly composed of two parts, an intracellular part for fast channel activation/deactivation and an extracellular part for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that BK channels, which are normally open, show a unique form of C-type inactivation that is closed state-dependent. This finding may help us understand the underlying mechanisms of BK channel regulation and disease. It may also lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of heart failure and stroke. Despite the development of antimalarial drugs and vector control, there is a need for new strategies to combat this disease. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of seasonal influenza outbreaks. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this process is limited. Here, we show that the brain encodes the structure of sentences by merging words into phrases. We provide evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be a fundamental step in the construction of language. © 2017, The Author(s).

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for development and homeostasis. Axin is a key component of the pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers differential responsiveness to the pathway. This is an example of how subtle differences in gene regulation can lead to differential responses to the same signal.

Obesity is a major health concern, and the mechanisms that regulate food intake are poorly understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra, and that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. These findings provide a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. They also suggest that this circuit may be a target for the development of new strategies for the treatment of obesity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and it is being rapidly deforested. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and deter deforestation. However, the effectiveness of these systems is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program that uses remote-sensed alerts to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests in response to alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring the effectiveness of externally facilitated community-based monitoring programs. This is a first step toward understanding the effectiveness of remote-sensed deforestation alerts. Future research should focus on the effectiveness of these systems in the field.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in form and function, and they are part of the animals’ bodies. Here, we show that the ears of the orb-weaving spider are not part of the spider’s body but are outsourced to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. The spider’s web is flexible and can be regularly regenerated, which enables it to functionally adjust and supersize its auditory surface area. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study provides insights into the evolution of the outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in animals. It also provides a unique model system for studying the sensing and manipulation of acoustic flows. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global health issues. We estimate the health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel and the reduction of other anthropogenic sources of air pollution. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuels can save 3.61 million lives per year, and a reduction of all anthropogenic sources can save 5.55 million lives per year. The phaseout of fossil fuels and the reduction of other anthropogenic sources can also reduce global temperature by 0.51 °C and 0.73 °C, respectively. The reduction of aerosols can restore rainfall patterns in many regions, and the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane can limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results show that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and other anthropogenic sources is needed to save millions of lives and restore the health of the planet. © 2017, The Author(s). These results suggest that the engineered RBD can be used in a variety of vaccine formats to provide a global vaccine solution. Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the underlying molecular mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish skin and nervous system. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings may lead to the development of zebrafish as a model system for the study of ALK/Ltk signaling in neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a key event in the history of human disease. However, the history of this pathogen is poorly understood because of the scarcity of ancient genomes. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s evolution and ecology during this critical period. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not adapted to humans and that it rapidly spread across Eurasia. This study also reveals the presence of a flea-adapted form of the pathogen in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of the pathogen. Together, these data provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s early history and its role in human history. © 2022, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election. © 2022, The Author(s). All rights reserved

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on the North American Great Plains has not been well-characterized. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated SOC in the top 15 cm of soil. These practices also enhance soil microbial biomass and C-use efficiency, but do not significantly increase the accumulation of mineral-bound microbial biomass. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC on North American agricultural soils. This study also highlights the importance of soil microbial traits in determining the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems. Our findings provide a framework for the development of soil health management practices that can be used to mitigate climate change and improve soil health on agricultural lands worldwide. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a global system to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans. We developed a framework to assess the risk of spillover of wildlife viruses to humans. We used this framework to prioritize 887 wildlife viruses, including 12 that have not previously been linked to disease outbreaks. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be used to inform research and public health interventions. This work provides a blueprint for the systematic identification of zoonotic threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of this reward is often yellow, but some plants produce red nectar. Here, we show that the red color of this reward is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this pigment. This work provides a molecular understanding of the evolution of a visually attractive reward.

The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations and invasions, which have shaped the genetic structure of the population today. However, the processes that led to the formation of the modern European population are not fully understood. Here, we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had been deformed by cranial cranial deformation. Our results indicate that these women had a genetic ancestry that was not represented in the population at the time. In addition, we show that many genes that are associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides new insights into the history of Europe. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens has led to a global need for rapid pathogen identification. We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to rapidly identify a variety of pathogens in resource-scarce settings. We demonstrate the feasibility of mNGS in a low-resource setting and the ability to detect vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of mNGS in resource-scarce settings to identify a variety of pathogens. This approach can be used to better understand the regional pathogen landscape and to deploy rapid public health response. This study is a step toward the development of mNGS as a platform for pathogen surveillance.

The human genome is replicated in a process called DNA replication. This process is essential for the survival of every cell in the body. It is also the process that is most prone to errors. The process of DNA replication is carried out by a complex of proteins called the replisome. The replisome is made up of many different proteins, but the most important are the DNA polymerase and the sliding clamp. The sliding clamp is responsible for keeping the polymerase in the correct position on the DNA. The polymerase is responsible for copying the DNA. The replisome is responsible for replicating the DNA.
The origin of life is one of the most important questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the ability of RNA to replicate itself.

Urban areas are the most populous places on Earth. They are also the most dynamic. They are changing rapidly, and they are changing in many different ways. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can reduce the mortality rate of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal. The maintenance of sufficient but nontoxic pools of copper is accomplished through diverse homeostasis mechanisms in fungi. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and have significant metal-dependent antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the modulation of interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study also provides a model for the discovery of fungal natural products that bind and impact cellular metal pools. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a rare example of a terrestrial mineral that formed at high temperatures on a planet other than Earth. The tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in the sedimentary rock are cogenetic, indicating that the rock formed in a single episode. The amorphous silica, possibly precipitated as precipitated silica, is a mixture of cations, and the crystalline magnetite is a primary precipitate or its diagenesis product. The post lithification fracture/vein fill is anhydrous. The diagenesis of the amorphous silica and the post lithification fracture/vein fill indicate that the sediment source region was a warm, wet environment. The diagenesis of the amorphous silica and the post lithification fracture/vein fill also indicate that the sediment source region and/or the sediment transport environment was a warm, wet environment.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a major concern for agriculture and forestry. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is strongly associated with the geographic distribution of frost events. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees to frost damage are strongly associated with the geographic distribution of frost events. These findings can be used to forecast the future vulnerability of forests to frost damage. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are poorly understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can directly transition to Th1-like cells and that Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease and for the development of therapeutic strategies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, environmental factors, and clinical phenotypes. The disease is also progressive, with motor neuron degeneration occurring in the absence of symptoms. Thus, there is a need for a disease model that can be used to study the disease in a short time, in a high-throughput manner, and in a patient-specific manner. Here, we report a method to generate motor neuron-specific astrocytes from living patients, which can be used to study the disease in a high-throughput manner. This method will enable the study of the disease in a patient-specific manner, and will lead to the development of new therapies. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick-harbored human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of a protein that alters the gut microbiota and facilitates infection. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the expression of a protein, antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates infection. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota and facilitates pathogen colonization. (Show more)

Birds are one of the most successful animal groups on Earth. However, our understanding of the early evolution of birds is limited by the lack of fossils. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle). This new taxon, named Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group.
We show that the stratosphere is a major source of climate forcing. This is a significant finding, as it implies that the climate system is more complex than previously thought.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. In some species, the color of the animal is determined by the presence of pigments in the skin. In others, the color is determined by the presence of pigments in the bones. In this study, we show that the presence of blue-green bones has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans (frogs and toads). We describe the molecular and functional basis of this phenomenon, which is called chlorosis.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells can be classified into two major populations: noncancerous cells and cancer stem cells (CSCs). CSCs are responsible for initiating and propagating the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5, a m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a CSC marker. Our results suggest that ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study also provides a mechanism for the role of ALKBH5 in the tumor microenvironment. The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbits, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This process may have been possible because of the tissue-thin nature of the parchment. © 2017, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key parameter in understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This age model will be critical in evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. © 2

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is characterized by the excessive activation of the immune system, leading to the destruction of the intestinal mucosa. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and not fully understood. Here, we show that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We further demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of IBD. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in currently circulating strains. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G spike is in a more open conformation, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results provide insight into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
