COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate the impact of COVID-19 on life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. Our projections indicate that the Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. These findings underscore the importance of addressing structural inequalities in health outcomes. © 2021, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry. They are also of great interest in the context of the origin of the chemical world, the origin of life, and the origin of the universe. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change under pressure, and that these changes can be predicted by a simple model. This model can be used to explain the origin of the chemical world, the origin of life, and the origin of the universe.

Fire is a natural and anthropogenic disturbance in terrestrial ecosystems. It is also a major source of greenhouse gases and air pollution. We quantify the effects of climate, socioeconomic, and fire management on global fire activity and carbon emissions. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to manage fire in a way that minimizes the risk of more extreme fires. This is especially important in fire-dependent ecosystems, such as tropical forests, where fire suppression has led to a buildup of fuel and a risk of catastrophic fires. Our study also highlights the importance of active fire management in reducing emissions and the risk of more extreme fires. Our results suggest that fire management can be a powerful tool in climate mitigation. However, the effectiveness of fire management depends on the fire regime and the risk of more extreme fires. Our results also suggest that climate change may be more effective in reducing warming than fire management. This highlights the importance of climate mitigation in reducing warming. The gut microbiota of animals is a major component of the host’s immune system. In this study, we show that the host provides a specific glycan to its symbiotic bacteria, which is catabolized by the bacteria to maintain the symbiosis. This glycan is only provided at night, when the host and bacteria are in close proximity in the symbiotic organ. This is the first example of a host providing a nutrient to its symbiotic bacteria, whose catabolism is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the activities of the gut microbiota in animals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Text data are ubiquitous and have been used to study a wide range of topics. However, the latent structure of text data is often unknown. In this paper, we introduce a method to identify the latent structure of text data. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding. We show that our method can be used to identify the latent structure of a large corpus of narratives about violent deaths. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope that our method will be used to study a wide range of topics in the future.

The Black Death, originating in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its impact on human societies. © 2017, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. They are also a valuable resource for humans, as they are a source of food and materials. In recent years, a disease has been observed that has led to the mass mortality of asteroids. In this study, we show that the disease is caused by a virus. We also show that the virus is present in the environment and in other echinoderms. This suggests that the virus is spread by the environment and other echinoderms. This is an important finding, as it has implications for the management of this important marine resource.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The disease is characterized by the presence of a small number of cells that are able to initiate and maintain the disease. These cells are thought to be the most primitive cells in the bone marrow, and they are responsible for the maintenance of the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor are able to target these cells and that this approach is effective in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that the antibody can be used to target the IL-1 signaling pathway, which is important for the growth of AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach could be used in combination with other therapies to improve the survival rate of AML patients. (Read more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a rapid growth of the population. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the history of Madagascar. It is a unique resource for the study of human evolution and the settlement of the Indian Ocean. It also provides a reference for the study of the history of Southeast Asia and Oceania. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also have broader implications for the development of other protein-based therapeutics.

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system. They provide information on the status of crops, which is used to manage the crop production cycle. However, the information provided by crop experts is qualitative and subjective, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by a large number of crop experts across the US, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used in quantitative analyses. We show that this transformation can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of harnessing the power of the “people as sensors” network to improve agricultural management. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries. Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it enables the binding of linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. © 2017, The Author(s).

The origin of plastids and their transition from a photosynthetic to a nonphotosynthetic lifestyle are among the most important evolutionary events in the history of life on Earth. The molecular signature of this transition is still poorly understood. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle, and that the loss of function is linked to the loss of photosynthesis. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This model can be used to understand the molecular evolution of plastid genomes in the context of the origin of life and the evolution of parasitic lifestyles. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a step towards quantifying the risk of future droughts in SSA. However, the results are limited by the coarse horizontal resolution of the model. This is a common challenge in the study of drought risk in SSA. We hope that this work will stimulate further research in this area. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the origin of these materials has remained a mystery. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this material, with its unique history, provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the development of the field of quasicrystal synthesis.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth. It is powered by the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The conversion of this energy is mediated by the (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments. These pigments are synthesized by a highly efficient biosynthetic pathway. The formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll pigments is a key step in this pathway. The biosynthesis of this ring is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. This diiron protein is the catalytic component of the oxygen-dependent cyclase. Here, we discuss the evolution of this enzyme. We also discuss the role of this enzyme in the biosynthesis of the chlorophyll pigments. Finally, we discuss the role of this enzyme in the oxygenic photosynthesis. (Read more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal pathways that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggest that the activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting is a common mechanism for autism-risk genes. This study also provides a powerful approach for identifying the converging functions of autism-risk genes. (PsycInfo Database Record

Stormorken syndrome is a rare, multisystem disorder characterized by bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein STIM1 and in ORAI1, the gene product of which is the CRAC channel pore-forming protein, are responsible for this disorder. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome and suggest new therapeutic strategies for patients with this disorder. This article is protected by copyright. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to vulnerable neurons. However, the mechanisms underlying the spreading of these aggregates are poorly understood. Here we show that the polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin accumulates in the brain and spreads throughout the brain in a model of Huntington’s disease. We show that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on endocytosis and that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection by selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Our findings may help to understand the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats and provide a potential strategy for the prevention and control of zoonotic disease outbreaks. Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth. One-carbon units are required for cell growth, and are supplied by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in human cancer cells blocks tumor growth. We then identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. These compounds are effective in cellular assays, and we show that they are particularly effective in B-cell lines. Finally, we show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These studies provide a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT1/2 as a cancer therapy. This work also provides a metabolic rationale for the use of glycine as a cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is a general feature of the disease. This may have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to have broad impact in the fields of atom optics, quantum information, and many-body physics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification is still controversial. Here, we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous that is sister to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. This study opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the diversification of some early flowering plant lineages.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature. They are known to cause a number of diseases, including fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from living species, but the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is unknown. Here we present the first ancient parvovirus genomes, which are from individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is ∼12.6 thousand years old, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the third parvovirus genotype to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. © 2017, The Author(s).

Sea level is rising on a global scale, and this rate is accelerating. This acceleration is a result of a combination of natural and anthropogenic processes. We estimate the rate of acceleration to be 0.084 mm/y2. This is in agreement with the IPCC AR5 estimate of 0.10 mm/y2.

Pain is a common and costly problem. In this paper, we show that pain has increased for all adults in America, but that the increase has been steeper for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not a recent phenomenon, but has been ongoing for several decades. If this trend continues, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzymes is a central theme in biology. In particular, the study of the active site of an enzyme, the site of catalysis, is a key component of understanding how the enzyme functions. Here, we describe the use of NMR-assisted crystallography to study the active site of an enzyme.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the mortality rate is high. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug used for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study may also lead to the development of a treatment for other diseases caused by coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of animals is known to influence host health and behavior, but the mechanisms by which this occurs are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by a host to its symbiotic bacteria is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and the production of bioluminescence at night. This glycan is delivered only at night, when the host is quiescent, and is catabolized by the symbionts, which are located in the crypts of the host organ. This study provides a mechanism by which the host can regulate the activities of its symbiotic bacteria. This may be a general mechanism by which host–microbe interactions are regulated. (Read more)

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that, by adopting an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, teachers can reduce suspension rates and improve students’ respect for them. Moreover, this intervention can be scaled up to affect large numbers of students and teachers. This is a scalable, evidence-based solution to a major social problem.

DNA alkylation is a major cause of mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on the transcriptional fidelity checkpoints and lesion bypass routes. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. In high-income countries, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. We show that a simple change to catering practices can have a large impact on the proportion of meals that are vegetarian. This has the potential to make a major contribution to the global environmental and health challenges. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available by 50% in cafeterias in one country could increase the proportion of vegetarian meals by 61.8% in that country alone, and by 20.4% in the whole world. This is equivalent to the proportion of the US population that is vegetarian today. Our results also suggest that the impact of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available could be enhanced by further increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available. This could be achieved by increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in other countries, or by increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in other types of catering outlets. Our results suggest that this is a promising area for further research.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment that is remodeled in cancer cells. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry and activated ion electron transfer dissociation to study the surface proteome of a panel of six oncogenes in a single cell line. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that has a modest positive effect on turnout. Our findings also suggest that the effects of vote-by-mail are likely to be similar across the political spectrum. Our results are consistent with the idea that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that has a modest positive effect on turnout. The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to a need for rapid development of vaccines and therapeutics. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV. This structure provides insight into the molecular basis for the rapid spread of the disease and the immune evasion and suppression activities of the virus. This structure will be critical for the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, and knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with increased expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes, both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed, and that exogenous CRF, acting through CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε. The up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using transfected CHO cells, we show that transfected CRFR1 contributes to edema via transfected AQP4. In conclusion, hypobaric hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. The world is full of associations. Some are interesting, some are spurious. It is important to be able to distinguish the interesting from the spurious. This paper describes a way to do this. It is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring significance when we have cherry-picked the data. We illustrate the method using three examples: stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The method can be applied to any statistical learning method. It is a powerful way to deal with the challenge of big data.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood vessel wall. They are responsible for maintaining the integrity of the vessel wall and transporting blood components. In addition, ECs are critical for the formation of new blood vessels, which is essential for the regeneration of organs. However, the generation of ECs has been difficult, and the minimum number of transcription factors that are required for the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs has not been defined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is sufficient to induce the direct conversion of human adult skin fibroblasts into functional ECs. This study provides a promising approach for the generation of ECs and the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as physiological ligands of the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that these ligands are activated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system for the study of the physiological role of orphan RTKs. It also provides a potential target for the development of new therapies for cancer and for the treatment of the defects observed in zebrafish deficient in augmentor ligands. β-Cell dysfunction is one of the main molecular bases for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global and β-cell–specific knockout mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING−/− beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction did not affect the HA titer of the mutant viruses, suggesting that the same amount of viral particles was produced. However, it nonspecifically decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire. In the last 20 y, humans have caused 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

Urban areas are the most populous places on Earth. They are also the most dynamic. They are changing rapidly, and they are changing in many different ways. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. We hope that this work will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of ZIKV is still unclear. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid production of virions, the short eclipse phase, and the role of the immune system in the control of the infection. We also provide estimates of the parameters of the model and of the potential impact of antiviral treatment. These results provide a framework for the design of future studies and for the development of new strategies to control the disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is a major barrier between the host and the environment. In the absence of tumors, the epithelium maintains a healthy microbiome and prevents systemic infections. However, in the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and systemic infections. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in the regulation of intestinal tumorigenesis and may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer treatment. Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer. However, the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and some patients do not respond to treatment. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to reestablish tumors in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab enhances the response to chemotherapy. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most enigmatic aspects of the last deglaciation. We show that the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation was linked to a volcanic eruption in West Antarctica, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes that were similar to those associated with modern ozone depletion over Antarctica. This finding provides a plausible explanation for the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation and the associated changes in climate and sea level.

Freshwater fisheries are a globally important source of food, recreation, and commerce. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also reveals that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poor and undernourished. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries are most likely to be sustainable and productive, and where conservation efforts should focus. This approach can help to protect the benefits that rivers provide to people and biodiversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. Aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely refractory to regeneration. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular control of regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, it may lead to new strategies for promoting regeneration in the CNS.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences, and it is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity. In many organisms, recombination occurs at specific sites, which are hotspots. In this paper, we describe the distribution of hotspots in the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that hotspots are interspersed among cold regions of low recombination. The distribution of hotspots is similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that hotspots may have been conserved since the origin of eukaryotes.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of interacting networks. The functional organization of the brain is not static, but changes over time, in response to external stimuli or internal processes. The resting brain can be divided into a small number of large-scale networks, which are topologically connected and functionally related. The present study provides a method for the identification of these networks, and their functional role in health and disease. The results provide a framework for the study of the organization of the brain, and its functional role in health and disease.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, the most studied example of a noncoding RNA, the 5′ end is modified with nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) to form 5′ NAD+ RNA. This modification has been shown to regulate gene expression, and it is found on a subset of mRNAs in yeast. Here we show that this modification is also found on mRNAs in human cells. We also show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is not found on pre-mRNAs, suggesting that it is not a general feature of the eukaryotic mRNA cap. Our results define a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could be important for the regulation of many cellular processes. (Read more)

The study of the epigenetic mechanisms of diabetes is of great interest because of the potential for the development of new therapeutic strategies. In this study, we show that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells is altered in people with diabetes and that this alteration persists for several years after the end of the study that first identified the epigenetic mechanism. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. They also provide a basis for future studies to determine whether these epigenetic changes can be targeted therapeutically. This would be a major advance in the treatment of diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and in the regulation of the psychological symptoms of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies. Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world, and their flavor is a major factor in their acceptance. The biosynthesis of the volatiles that contribute to the fruit aroma is not known. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major advance in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. It also opens the door to the development of new strategies for improving the quality of tomato fruit. Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have implications for the management of biodiversity and the design of climate change adaptation strategies. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub in the hippocampus, which is critical for spatial cognition. The organization of MEC is important for understanding the neural basis of spatial navigation and memory. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. Our data show that grid cells, which are critical for place learning, are anatomically segregated from other cell types. These data provide a detailed map of the organization of MEC and will be useful for future studies of the neural basis of spatial cognition. This article is protected by copyright. Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model system for studying the flowering of parasitic plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study provides a unique view of the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system. It also suggests that the striosome–dendron bouquets are specialized integrative units within the system. This organization may be important for the control of movement and motivation. It could also be relevant to human disorders of the dopamine system. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We have long sought to understand how this connection is made. In this work, we show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected they feel. This effect is not the result of conscious control, and it is not the result of a conscious preference for fast responses. Rather, it is a signal of connection that is used by others to gauge the quality of the connection between two people. This finding has implications for how we design social systems, how we design human–computer interaction, and how we design our own social interactions. It also has implications for our understanding of the evolution of human sociality.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes that are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. We found that the calcium sensor STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is required for the normal function of the SAN. Our results suggest that STIM1 is a regulator of calcium dynamics in the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the heart rate. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has been controversial. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance against the rice leaffolder in rice plants, and that this effect is dependent on jasmonate (JA) signaling. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have implications for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the regulation of macrophage activation. This article is protected by copyright. Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neural populations. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This is a biologically plausible account of memory that does not rely on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. It is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and medicine for the human population. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up a new avenue for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient pollution from small streams is a growing concern for coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, the relative importance of small and large tributaries has not been well quantified. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that the 6 largest tributaries accounted for ∼70% of the daily nitrogen and phosphorus delivered to Lake Michigan. However, small tributaries exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that small watersheds may play a greater role in fueling coastal algal blooms than previously appreciated. Our findings highlight the importance of small streams in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This is especially important given the likelihood that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small subset of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node bifurcation” in dynamical systems theory, which is a well-known mechanism for the emergence of complex dynamics. Our results suggest that the saddle-node bifurcation may be a general mechanism for the emergence of complex dynamics in complex networks of chemical reactions. We show that this can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities, which are a common feature of the condition. We also show that the paroxysms are caused by changes in the brain’s intrinsic microcircuitry. These findings offer insights into the mechanisms of the condition and may lead to new therapeutic strategies. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event. To understand the potential for future abrupt climate change, it is important to understand the history of abrupt climate change in the past. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was driven by a global warming event that was superimposed on a longer-term greenhouse climate state. The event was also linked to a major extinction.

Certification of palm oil is a major policy tool to reduce tropical deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation and fire in oil palm plantations has not been well studied. We use a unique dataset of oil palm plantations in Indonesia to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire. We find that certification reduced deforestation by 33% from 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification has not yet achieved its potential to reduce deforestation in Indonesia. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results also highlight the importance of certification in the context of other policies, such as the moratorium on new concessions, to reduce tropical deforestation. The exocytosis process is essential for the functioning of all organisms. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is critical for the release of proteins from the trans-Golgi network. In humans, the dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study. In many species, sex is determined by a single genetic locus, resulting in two sexes. In other species, sex is determined by multiple interacting loci, resulting in more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination loci in a species with four genotypic sexes. We find that multiple sex determination loci can result in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be used to understand the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Read more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and Fe is a key redox factor. We show that Fe levels in the retina can be manipulated by the Fe chelator deferiprone. We also show that Fe levels in the retina can influence the levels of a class of molecules that are implicated in age-related vision loss. These findings have implications for understanding the role of Fe in the retina and for developing strategies to protect the retina from oxidative damage. (Read more)

Predators are the foundation of most food webs, and the evolution of their feeding strategies has shaped the structure of ecosystems. However, the evolution of specialization in predators has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores has led to the evolution of specialization in other predators. Our results contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization in predators, and the role of morphological innovation in the diversification of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution. However, the origin of the derived features of the modern human hand are poorly understood because of a lack of fossil evidence from the time of their origin. Here we report the discovery of the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of the complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand. This finding suggests that the evolution of the human hand was more rapid than previously thought. It also suggests that the evolution of the Neandertal hand was more recent than previously thought. These findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the hominin lineage.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth. One-carbon units are required for cell growth, and are supplied by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is a promising target for cancer therapy, but the enzyme is also critical for normal cell growth. Here we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks tumor growth in mice. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate can rescue cells from the inhibitor, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. This is because formate is a substrate for SHMT, and thus the enzyme is required to meet demand for formate in cancer cells. Thus, formate is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. These findings provide a metabolic rationale for the use of formate as a cancer therapeutic. They also provide a metabolic rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in cancer therapy. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. This finding has important implications for policy makers, who have largely overlooked forests in strategies to improve nutrition. Our results suggest that forests offer a potential “win–win" solution to the triple crisis.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, increasing food production worldwide. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
